thread.title: "Just mind-blowing" - Lincoln hero Sean Raggett on writing his name into FA Cup folklore
thread.title_full: "Just mind-blowing" - Lincoln hero Sean Raggett on writing his name into FA Cup folklore

author: David Maddock
title: "Just mind-blowing" - Lincoln hero Sean Raggett on writing his name into FA Cup folklore

organizations.name: lincoln city of the national league

text:
The goal that won it (Photo: AFP) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Sean Raggett knows he has just found himself in the middle of history as it is happening, but he has a confession. 
“I’ll be honest I haven’t heard of him, it’s the first time I’ve heard of that - but it’s crazy to be put in that bracket. It’s madness isn’t it - just mind-blowing.” 
He is talking about Ronnie Radford and quite probably the most famous giant killing goal of all time. Raggett realises he has just done something that could be remembered and repeated in 40 years time, just like the Hereford hero. 
Yet at 23, his FA Cup knowledge is more limited, his own memories far more recent. He knows the competition writes football legend though, even if he can’t quite take it all in just yet. Raggett heads home to stun the Premier League side (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Raggett celebrates his winner (Photo: REUTERS) 
“People are saying to me that scoring the goal in a game like that writes you name in the history books, and it’s hard to get your head around it,” he explains, with an almost bemused smile. 
“My earliest memory as a kid was the FA Cup final, Arsenal beat Chelsea 2-0, when Ray Parlour curled that goal in the top corner. 
“That’s my earliest football memory, it’s a great competition you love as a kid, and to be involved, to get this far and be in the quarter final it is just unreal, it really is. It’s unheard of in modern day football for a non league team to get to the quarter final, so it’s crazy isn’t it.” Raggett knows little about Hereford hero Ronnie Radford (Photo: Mirrorpix) But he's well aware of Ray Parlour after his Arsenal exploits in 2002 (Photo: Reuters) 
Even in these surreal times, it IS crazy. 
Lincoln City of the National League, 81 places below Burnley, are the first non league team in 103 years to reach the quarter finals of the world’s oldest, most glittering competition. 
They did it by beating, in their own stadium, a team who have the third best home record in the Premier League. And it was no fluke - they were the better team. 
Their management team of Danny and Nicky Cowley created with almost military precision a game-plan designed to frustrate Burnley, and to exploit the innate complacency and confusion of dealing with opponents from a different world. 
The plan - the dream - was to keep the game tight, to restrict their opponents and exploit set pieces, particularly at the end. Especially at the end, when there was little time to retaliate. Delighted Lincoln chief Danny Cowley (Photo: Clive Brunskill) Lincoln players could barely believe it themselves (Photo: REUTERS) 
The dream became reality when Raggett forced the ball home, after central defensive partner Luke Waterfall had nodded back a Sam Habergham corner while the entire Burnley team were rooted in slack-jawed horror. 
Afterwards, the entire Lincoln team were insistent they genuinely arrived at Turf Moor with a victory plan, as Raggett explained. “Honestly, we came here to win the game, with the belief we could, but still to actually achieve it is just incredible. 
“You know what, when we got those two corners at the end I thought, ‘this is us, this is out chance now’, because we worked so hard at set pieces in the build up to the game, and I thought if we are gonna win this game it’s gonna be now. 
“We been working on the set pieces and it’s been going through my head all week that I’ll be up there in the middle of them, so for it to come off, for me to get the goal is unbelievable.” Lincoln City fans celebrate as they watch the Emirates FA Cup draw (Photo: PA) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
